sourcesContent:
const About = () => { return (

I love problem solving, and I'm annoyed when things aren't quite right. I'm a developer.

See, I was born with the “there must be a better way” gene & that ethos permeates every aspect of my life:

In my code, this manifests as some pretty good intuition when my work isn't DRY. To optimize my code, I regularly ask seniors targeted questions & learn from their experiences.

Maintainable & easy to understand code is always my goal. I love elegant & modular code blocks that provide a seamless user-experience.

Also, no app exists in a silo— code is collaborative. So, I'm always striving to understand the bigger picture of what I'm working on to connect new learnings with past knowledge & ensure that my contributions integrate well into wider codebases.

I believe that all problems have solutions— It's just a matter of having the patience to find the solution that will make the user's experience just right.

My “there must be a better way” ethos also contributed to my 5+ year track record of solving user-focus problems in my past-life as a Technical Apparel Developer.

My main focus in this role was to execute the design team's vision of each season's collection while protecting & improving best-in-class fit & function of each garment (read: user-experience). My work was iterative, and involved weekly research to identify user pain points— Is it warm enough? Is the pocket in an intuitive place? Can you sit down comfortably? Does it fit as expected?

From there, I would research, prototype, & test solutions before sending the best solution to stores (read: push to production). User experience was quantified in True To Size (TTS) ratings & calculated from online reviews. I improved the user experience by 9% to an average of 94% TTS.

); } export default About;
